segment.source: Create and deploy an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using System Center Configuration Manager (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create and deploy an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using System Center Configuration Manager (Windows 10)

segment.source: Configuration Manager (version 1511 or later) helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.
segment.target: Configuration Manager (version 1511 or later) helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.

segment.source: Create and deploy an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using System Center Configuration Manager
segment.target: Create and deploy an enterprise data protection (EDP) policy using System Center Configuration Manager

segment.source: Applies to:
segment.target: Applies to:

segment.source: Windows 10 Insider Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Insider Preview

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile Preview
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile Preview

segment.source: System Center Configuration Manager (version 1511 or later)
segment.target: System Center Configuration Manager (version 1511 or later)

segment.source: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: [Some information relates to pre-released product, which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.]

segment.source: Configuration Manager (version 1511 or later) helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.
segment.target: Configuration Manager (version 1511 or later) helps you create and deploy your enterprise data protection (EDP) policy, including letting you choose your protected apps, your EDP-protection level, and how to find enterprise data on the network.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Add an EDP policy
segment.target: Add an EDP policy

segment.source: Choose which apps can access your enterprise data
segment.target: Choose which apps can access your enterprise data

segment.source: Manage the EDP protection level for your enterprise data
segment.target: Manage the EDP protection level for your enterprise data

segment.source: Define your enterprise-managed identity domains
segment.target: Define your enterprise-managed identity domains

segment.source: Choose where apps can access enterprise data
segment.target: Choose where apps can access enterprise data

segment.source: Choose your optional EDP-related settings
segment.target: Choose your optional EDP-related settings

segment.source: Review your configuration choices in the Summary screen
segment.target: Review your configuration choices in the Summary screen

segment.source: Deploy the EDP policy
segment.target: Deploy the EDP policy

segment.source: Add an EDP policy
segment.target: Add an EDP policy

segment.source: After you’ve installed and set up System Center Configuration Manager for your organization, you must create a configuration item for EDP, which in turn becomes your EDP policy.
segment.target: After you’ve installed and set up System Center Configuration Manager for your organization, you must create a configuration item for EDP, which in turn becomes your EDP policy.

segment.source: To create a configuration item for EDP
segment.target: To create a configuration item for EDP

segment.source: Open the System Center Configuration Manager console, click the Assets and Compliance node, expand the Overview node, expand the Compliance Settings node, and then expand the Configuration Items node.
segment.target: Open the System Center Configuration Manager console, click the Assets and Compliance node, expand the Overview node, expand the Compliance Settings node, and then expand the Configuration Items node.

segment.source: System Center Configuration Manager, Configuration Items screen
segment.target: System Center Configuration Manager, Configuration Items screen

segment.source: Click the Create Configuration Item button.
segment.target: Click the Create Configuration Item button.

segment.source: The Create Configuration Item Wizard starts.
segment.target: The Create Configuration Item Wizard starts.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, define the configuration item and choose the configuration type
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, define the configuration item and choose the configuration type

segment.source: On the General Information screen, type a name (required) and an optional description for your policy into the Name and Description boxes.
segment.target: On the General Information screen, type a name (required) and an optional description for your policy into the Name and Description boxes.

segment.source: In the Specify the type of configuration item you want to create area, pick the option that represents whether you use System Center Configuration Manager for device management, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Specify the type of configuration item you want to create area, pick the option that represents whether you use System Center Configuration Manager for device management, and then click Next.

segment.source: Settings for devices managed with the Configuration Manager client: Windows 10
segment.target: Settings for devices managed with the Configuration Manager client: Windows 10

segment.source: -OR-
segment.target: -OR-

segment.source: Settings for devices managed without the Configuration Manager client: Windows 8.1 and Windows 10
segment.target: Settings for devices managed without the Configuration Manager client: Windows 8.1 and Windows 10

segment.source: On the Supported Platforms screen, click the Windows 10 box, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Supported Platforms screen, click the Windows 10 box, and then click Next.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose the supported platforms for the policy
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose the supported platforms for the policy

segment.source: On the Device Settings screen, click Enterprise Data Protection, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Device Settings screen, click Enterprise Data Protection, and then click Next.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose the enterprise data protection settings
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose the enterprise data protection settings

segment.source: The Configure Enterprise Data Protection settings page appears, where you'll configure your policy for your organization.
segment.target: The Configure Enterprise Data Protection settings page appears, where you'll configure your policy for your organization.

segment.source: Choose which apps can access your enterprise data
segment.target: Choose which apps can access your enterprise data

segment.source: During the policy-creation process in Configuration Manager, you can choose the apps you want to give access to your enterprise data through EDP.
segment.target: During the policy-creation process in Configuration Manager, you can choose the apps you want to give access to your enterprise data through EDP.

segment.source: Apps included in this list can protect data on behalf of the enterprise and are restricted from copying or moving enterprise data to unprotected apps or unprotected network locations.
segment.target: Apps included in this list can protect data on behalf of the enterprise and are restricted from copying or moving enterprise data to unprotected apps or unprotected network locations.

segment.source: The steps to add your apps are based on the type of app it is; either a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, or a signed Classic Windows application.
segment.target: The steps to add your apps are based on the type of app it is; either a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app, or a signed Classic Windows application.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: EDP-aware apps are expected to prevent enterprise data from going to unprotected network locations and to avoid encrypting personal data.
segment.target: EDP-aware apps are expected to prevent enterprise data from going to unprotected network locations and to avoid encrypting personal data.

segment.source: On the other hand, EDP-unaware apps might not respect the corporate network boundary and will encrypt all files they create or modify, meaning that they could encrypt personal data and cause data leaks during the revocation process.
segment.target: On the other hand, EDP-unaware apps might not respect the corporate network boundary and will encrypt all files they create or modify, meaning that they could encrypt personal data and cause data leaks during the revocation process.

segment.source: Care must be taken to get a support statement from the software provider that their app is safe with EDP before adding it to your Protected App list.
segment.target: Care must be taken to get a support statement from the software provider that their app is safe with EDP before adding it to your Protected App list.

segment.source: To add a UWP app
segment.target: To add a UWP app

segment.source: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.
segment.target: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.

segment.source: Click Universal App, type the Publisher Name and the Product Name into the associated boxes, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Universal App, type the Publisher Name and the Product Name into the associated boxes, and then click OK.

segment.source: If you don't have the publisher or product name, you can find them by following these steps.
segment.target: If you don't have the publisher or product name, you can find them by following these steps.

segment.source: To find the Publisher and Product name values for Microsoft Store apps without installing them
segment.target: To find the Publisher and Product name values for Microsoft Store apps without installing them

segment.source: Go to the Windows Store for Business website, and find your app.
segment.target: Go to the Windows Store for Business website, and find your app.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft OneNote.
segment.target: For example, Microsoft OneNote.

segment.source: Copy the ID value from the app URL.
segment.target: Copy the ID value from the app URL.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft OneNote's ID URL is https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/onenote/9wzdncrfhvjl, and you'd copy the ID value, .
segment.target: For example, Microsoft OneNote's ID URL is https://www.microsoft.com/store/apps/onenote/9wzdncrfhvjl, and you'd copy the ID value, .

segment.source: In a browser, run the Store for Business portal web API, to return a JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) file that includes the publisher and product name values.
segment.target: In a browser, run the Store for Business portal web API, to return a JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) file that includes the publisher and product name values.

segment.source: For example, run https://bspmts.mp.microsoft.com/v1/public/catalog/Retail/Products/9wzdncrfhvjl/applockerdata, where 9wzdncrfhvjl is replaced with your ID value.
segment.target: For example, run https://bspmts.mp.microsoft.com/v1/public/catalog/Retail/Products/9wzdncrfhvjl/applockerdata, where 9wzdncrfhvjl is replaced with your ID value.

segment.source: The API runs and opens a text editor with the app details.
segment.target: The API runs and opens a text editor with the app details.

segment.source: Copy the value and paste them into the Publisher Name box, copy the value into the Product Name box of the Add app box, and then click OK.
segment.target: Copy the value and paste them into the Publisher Name box, copy the value into the Product Name box of the Add app box, and then click OK.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: If you don’t see the Product Name box, it could mean that your tenant is not on the latest build and that you need to wait until it's upgraded.
segment.target: If you don’t see the Product Name box, it could mean that your tenant is not on the latest build and that you need to wait until it's upgraded.

segment.source: Same applies if you see the AppId box.
segment.target: Same applies if you see the AppId box.

segment.source: The AppId box has been removed in the latest build and should disappear (along with any entries) when your tenant is upgraded.
segment.target: The AppId box has been removed in the latest build and should disappear (along with any entries) when your tenant is upgraded.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The JSON file might also return a value for both the Publisher Name and Product Name boxes.
segment.target: The JSON file might also return a value for both the Publisher Name and Product Name boxes.

segment.source: This means that you have an app that’s using a XAP package and that you must set the Product Name as , and set the Publisher Name as “CN=” followed by the .
segment.target: This means that you have an app that’s using a XAP package and that you must set the Product Name as , and set the Publisher Name as “CN=” followed by the .

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, add a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, add a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app

segment.source: To add a Classic Windows application
segment.target: To add a Classic Windows application

segment.source: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.
segment.target: From the Configure the following apps to be protected by EDP table in the Protected Apps area, click Add.

segment.source: A dialog box appears, letting you pick whether the app is a Universal App or a Desktop App.
segment.target: A dialog box appears, letting you pick whether the app is a Universal App or a Desktop App.

segment.source: Click Desktop App, pick the options you want (see table), and then click OK.
segment.target: Click Desktop App, pick the options you want (see table), and then click OK.

segment.source: Option
segment.target: Option

segment.source: Manages
segment.target: Manages

segment.source: All fields left as “*”
segment.target: All fields left as “*”

segment.source: All files signed by any publisher.
segment.target: All files signed by any publisher.

segment.source: (Not recommended.)
segment.target: (Not recommended.)

segment.source: Publisher selected
segment.target: Publisher selected

segment.source: All files signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: All files signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: This might be useful if your company is the publisher and signer of internal line-of-business apps.
segment.target: This might be useful if your company is the publisher and signer of internal line-of-business apps.

segment.source: Publisher and Product Name selected
segment.target: Publisher and Product Name selected

segment.source: All files for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: All files for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, and File Name selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, and File Name selected

segment.source: Any version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Any version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, Exactly, selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, Exactly, selected

segment.source: Specified version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Specified version of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And above selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And above selected

segment.source: Specified version or newer releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Specified version or newer releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: This option is recommended for enlightened apps that weren't previously enlightened.
segment.target: This option is recommended for enlightened apps that weren't previously enlightened.

segment.source: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And below selected
segment.target: Publisher, Product Name, File Name, and File Version, And below selected

segment.source: Specified version or older releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.
segment.target: Specified version or older releases of the named file or package for the specified product, signed by the named publisher.

segment.source: If you’re unsure about what to include for the publisher, you can run this PowerShell command:
segment.target: If you’re unsure about what to include for the publisher, you can run this PowerShell command:

segment.source: Where goes to the location of the app on the device.
segment.target: Where goes to the location of the app on the device.

segment.source: For example, .
segment.target: For example, .

segment.source: In this example, you'd get the following info:
segment.target: In this example, you'd get the following info:

segment.source: Where the text, is the publisher name to enter in the Publisher Name box.
segment.target: Where the text, is the publisher name to enter in the Publisher Name box.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, add a Classic Windows app
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, add a Classic Windows app

segment.source: Manage the EDP-protection level for your enterprise data
segment.target: Manage the EDP-protection level for your enterprise data

segment.source: After you've added the apps you want to protect with EDP, you'll need to apply an app management mode.
segment.target: After you've added the apps you want to protect with EDP, you'll need to apply an app management mode.

segment.source: We recommend that you start with Silent or Override while verifying with a small group that you have the right apps on your Protected Apps list.
segment.target: We recommend that you start with Silent or Override while verifying with a small group that you have the right apps on your Protected Apps list.

segment.source: After you're done, you can change to your final enforcement policy, either Override or Block.
segment.target: After you're done, you can change to your final enforcement policy, either Override or Block.

segment.source: Mode
segment.target: Mode

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Block
segment.target: Block

segment.source: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing practices and stops the employee from completing the action.
segment.target: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing practices and stops the employee from completing the action.

segment.source: This can include sharing info across non-enterprise-protected apps in addition to sharing enterprise data between other people and devices outside of your enterprise.
segment.target: This can include sharing info across non-enterprise-protected apps in addition to sharing enterprise data between other people and devices outside of your enterprise.

segment.source: Override
segment.target: Override

segment.source: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing, warning employees if they do something deemed potentially unsafe.
segment.target: EDP looks for inappropriate data sharing, warning employees if they do something deemed potentially unsafe.

segment.source: However, this management mode lets the employee override the policy and share the data, logging the action to your audit log, accessible through the Reporting CSP.
segment.target: However, this management mode lets the employee override the policy and share the data, logging the action to your audit log, accessible through the Reporting CSP.

segment.source: Silent
segment.target: Silent

segment.source: EDP runs silently, logging inappropriate data sharing, without blocking anything.
segment.target: EDP runs silently, logging inappropriate data sharing, without blocking anything.

segment.source: Off (not recommended)
segment.target: Off (not recommended)

segment.source: EDP is turned off and doesn't help to protect or audit your data.
segment.target: EDP is turned off and doesn't help to protect or audit your data.

segment.source: After you turn off EDP, an attempt is made to decrypt any closed EDP-tagged files on the locally attached drives.
segment.target: After you turn off EDP, an attempt is made to decrypt any closed EDP-tagged files on the locally attached drives.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose your EDP-protection level
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose your EDP-protection level

segment.source: Define your enterprise-managed identity domains
segment.target: Define your enterprise-managed identity domains

segment.source: Specify your company’s enterprise identity, expressed as your primary internet domain.
segment.target: Specify your company’s enterprise identity, expressed as your primary internet domain.

segment.source: For example, if your company is Contoso, its enterprise identity might be contoso.com.
segment.target: For example, if your company is Contoso, its enterprise identity might be contoso.com.

segment.source: The first listed domain (in this example, contoso.com) is the primary enterprise identity string used to tag files protected by any app on the Protected App list.
segment.target: The first listed domain (in this example, contoso.com) is the primary enterprise identity string used to tag files protected by any app on the Protected App list.

segment.source: You can also specify all the domains owned by your enterprise that are used for user accounts, separating them with the "|" character.
segment.target: You can also specify all the domains owned by your enterprise that are used for user accounts, separating them with the "|" character.

segment.source: For example, if Contoso also has some employees with email addresses or user accounts on the fabrikam.com domain, you would use contoso.com|fabrikam.com.
segment.target: For example, if Contoso also has some employees with email addresses or user accounts on the fabrikam.com domain, you would use contoso.com|fabrikam.com.

segment.source: This list of managed identity domains, along with the primary domain, make up the identity of your managing enterprise.
segment.target: This list of managed identity domains, along with the primary domain, make up the identity of your managing enterprise.

segment.source: User identities (user@domain) that end in any of the domains on this list, are considered managed.
segment.target: User identities (user@domain) that end in any of the domains on this list, are considered managed.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, Add the primary Internet domain for your enterprise identity
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, Add the primary Internet domain for your enterprise identity

segment.source: To add your primary domain
segment.target: To add your primary domain

segment.source: Type the name of your primary domain into the Primary domain field.
segment.target: Type the name of your primary domain into the Primary domain field.

segment.source: For example, contoso.com.
segment.target: For example, contoso.com.

segment.source: If you have multiple domains, you must separate them with the "|" character.
segment.target: If you have multiple domains, you must separate them with the "|" character.

segment.source: For example, contoso.com|fabrikam.com.
segment.target: For example, contoso.com|fabrikam.com.

segment.source: Choose where apps can access enterprise data
segment.target: Choose where apps can access enterprise data

segment.source: After you've added a management level to your protected apps, you'll need to decide where those apps can access enterprise data on your network.
segment.target: After you've added a management level to your protected apps, you'll need to decide where those apps can access enterprise data on your network.

segment.source: There are 6 options, including your network domain, cloud domain, proxy server, internal proxy server, IPv4 range, and IPv6 range.
segment.target: There are 6 options, including your network domain, cloud domain, proxy server, internal proxy server, IPv4 range, and IPv6 range.

segment.source: To specify where your protected apps can find and send enterprise data on the network
segment.target: To specify where your protected apps can find and send enterprise data on the network

segment.source: Add additional network locations your apps can access by clicking Add, and then choosing your location type, including:
segment.target: Add additional network locations your apps can access by clicking Add, and then choosing your location type, including:

segment.source: Network location type
segment.target: Network location type

segment.source: Format
segment.target: Format

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Enterprise Cloud Domain
segment.target: Enterprise Cloud Domain

segment.source: contoso.sharepoint.com,proxy1.contoso.com|
segment.target: contoso.sharepoint.com,proxy1.contoso.com|

segment.source: office.com|proxy2.contoso.com
segment.target: office.com|proxy2.contoso.com

segment.source: Specify the cloud resources traffic to restrict to your protected apps.
segment.target: Specify the cloud resources traffic to restrict to your protected apps.

segment.source: For each cloud resource, you may also specify an internal proxy server that routes your traffic from your Enterprise Internal Proxy Server policy.
segment.target: For each cloud resource, you may also specify an internal proxy server that routes your traffic from your Enterprise Internal Proxy Server policy.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must use the | delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must use the | delimiter.

segment.source: Include the "|" delimiter just before the "|" if you don’t use proxies.
segment.target: Include the "|" delimiter just before the "|" if you don’t use proxies.

segment.source: For example: [URL,Proxy]|[URL,Proxy].
segment.target: For example: [URL,Proxy]|[URL,Proxy].

segment.source: Enterprise Network Domain
segment.target: Enterprise Network Domain

segment.source: domain1.contoso.com,domain2.contoso.com
segment.target: domain1.contoso.com,domain2.contoso.com

segment.source: Specify the DNS suffix used in your environment.
segment.target: Specify the DNS suffix used in your environment.

segment.source: All traffic to the fully-qualified domains using this DNS suffix will be protected.
segment.target: All traffic to the fully-qualified domains using this DNS suffix will be protected.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must use the "," delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must use the "," delimiter.

segment.source: This setting works with the IP Ranges settings to detect whether a network endpoint is enterprise or personal on private networks.
segment.target: This setting works with the IP Ranges settings to detect whether a network endpoint is enterprise or personal on private networks.

segment.source: Enterprise Proxy Server
segment.target: Enterprise Proxy Server

segment.source: domain1.contoso.com:80;domain2.contoso.com:137
segment.target: domain1.contoso.com:80;domain2.contoso.com:137

segment.source: Specify the proxy server and the port traffic is routed through.
segment.target: Specify the proxy server and the port traffic is routed through.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must use the ";" delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must use the ";" delimiter.

segment.source: This setting is required if you use a proxy in your network.
segment.target: This setting is required if you use a proxy in your network.

segment.source: If you don't have a proxy server, you might find that enterprise resources are unavailable when a client is behind a proxy, such as when using certain Wi-Fi hotspots at hotels and restaurants.
segment.target: If you don't have a proxy server, you might find that enterprise resources are unavailable when a client is behind a proxy, such as when using certain Wi-Fi hotspots at hotels and restaurants.

segment.source: Enterprise Internal Proxy Server
segment.target: Enterprise Internal Proxy Server

segment.source: proxy1.contoso.com;proxy2.contoso.com
segment.target: proxy1.contoso.com;proxy2.contoso.com

segment.source: Specify the proxy servers your cloud resources will go through.
segment.target: Specify the proxy servers your cloud resources will go through.

segment.source: If you have multiple resources, you must use the ";" delimiter.
segment.target: If you have multiple resources, you must use the ";" delimiter.

segment.source: Enterprise IPv4 Range
segment.target: Enterprise IPv4 Range

segment.source: Starting IPv4 Address: 3.4.0.1
segment.target: Starting IPv4 Address: 3.4.0.1

segment.source: Ending IPv4 Address: 3.4.255.254
segment.target: Ending IPv4 Address: 3.4.255.254

segment.source: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv4 value range within your intranet.
segment.target: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv4 value range within your intranet.

segment.source: If you are adding a single range, you can enter the starting and ending addresses into your management system’s UI.
segment.target: If you are adding a single range, you can enter the starting and ending addresses into your management system’s UI.

segment.source: If you want to add multiple addresses, we suggest creating a Custom URI, using the "-" delimiter between start and end of a range, and the "," delimiter to separate ranges.
segment.target: If you want to add multiple addresses, we suggest creating a Custom URI, using the "-" delimiter between start and end of a range, and the "," delimiter to separate ranges.

segment.source: Enterprise IPv6 Range
segment.target: Enterprise IPv6 Range

segment.source: Starting IPv6 Address: 2a01:110::
segment.target: Starting IPv6 Address: 2a01:110::

segment.source: Ending IPv6 Address: 2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff
segment.target: Ending IPv6 Address: 2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff

segment.source: Custom URI: 2a01:110::-2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff,fd00::-fdff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff
segment.target: Custom URI: 2a01:110::-2a01:110:7fff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff,fd00::-fdff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff

segment.source: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv6 value range within your intranet.
segment.target: Specify the addresses for a valid IPv6 value range within your intranet.

segment.source: If you are adding a single range, you can enter the starting and ending addresses into your management system’s UI.
segment.target: If you are adding a single range, you can enter the starting and ending addresses into your management system’s UI.

segment.source: If you want to add multiple addresses, we suggest creating a Custom URI, using the "-" delimiter between start and end of a range, and the "," delimiter to separate ranges.
segment.target: If you want to add multiple addresses, we suggest creating a Custom URI, using the "-" delimiter between start and end of a range, and the "," delimiter to separate ranges.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, specify the network locations that can be accessed by the protected apps
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, specify the network locations that can be accessed by the protected apps

segment.source: Add as many locations as you need, and then click OK.
segment.target: Add as many locations as you need, and then click OK.

segment.source: The Add or Edit Enterprise Network Locations box closes.
segment.target: The Add or Edit Enterprise Network Locations box closes.

segment.source: In the Use a data recovery certificate in case of data loss box, click Browse to add a data recovery certificate for your policy.
segment.target: In the Use a data recovery certificate in case of data loss box, click Browse to add a data recovery certificate for your policy.

segment.source: Adding a data recovery certificate helps you to access locally-protected files on the device.
segment.target: Adding a data recovery certificate helps you to access locally-protected files on the device.

segment.source: For example, if an employee leaves the company and the IT department has to access EDP-protected data from a Windows 10 company computer.
segment.target: For example, if an employee leaves the company and the IT department has to access EDP-protected data from a Windows 10 company computer.

segment.source: This can also help recover data in case an employee's device is accidentally revoked.
segment.target: This can also help recover data in case an employee's device is accidentally revoked.

segment.source: For more info about how to find and export your data recovery certificate, see theData Recovery and Encrypting File System (EFS) topic.
segment.target: For more info about how to find and export your data recovery certificate, see theData Recovery and Encrypting File System (EFS) topic.

segment.source: Choose your optional EDP-related settings
segment.target: Choose your optional EDP-related settings

segment.source: After you've decided where your protected apps can access enterprise data on your network, you’ll be asked to decide if you want to add any optional EDP settings.
segment.target: After you've decided where your protected apps can access enterprise data on your network, you’ll be asked to decide if you want to add any optional EDP settings.

segment.source: To add your optional settings
segment.target: To add your optional settings

segment.source: Choose to set any or all of the optional EDP-related settings:
segment.target: Choose to set any or all of the optional EDP-related settings:

segment.source: Block the user from decrypting data that was created or edited by the apps configured above.
segment.target: Block the user from decrypting data that was created or edited by the apps configured above.

segment.source: Clicking No, or leaving the setting blank, lets your employees right-click to decrypt their protected app data, along with the option to decrypt data in the Save As box and the Save As file picker .
segment.target: Clicking No, or leaving the setting blank, lets your employees right-click to decrypt their protected app data, along with the option to decrypt data in the Save As box and the Save As file picker .

segment.source: Clicking Yes removes the Decrypt option and saves all data for protected apps as enterprise-encrypted.
segment.target: Clicking Yes removes the Decrypt option and saves all data for protected apps as enterprise-encrypted.

segment.source: Protect app content when the device is in a locked state for the apps configured above.
segment.target: Protect app content when the device is in a locked state for the apps configured above.

segment.source: Clicking Yes lets EDP help to secure protected app content when a mobile device is locked.
segment.target: Clicking Yes lets EDP help to secure protected app content when a mobile device is locked.

segment.source: We recommend turning this option on to help prevent data leaks from things such as email text that appears on the Lock screen of a Windows 10 Mobile phone.
segment.target: We recommend turning this option on to help prevent data leaks from things such as email text that appears on the Lock screen of a Windows 10 Mobile phone.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose additional optional settings for enterprise data protection
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, choose additional optional settings for enterprise data protection

segment.source: Review your configuration choices in the Summary screen
segment.target: Review your configuration choices in the Summary screen

segment.source: After you've finished configuring your policy, you can review all of your info on the Summary screen.
segment.target: After you've finished configuring your policy, you can review all of your info on the Summary screen.

segment.source: To view the Summary screen
segment.target: To view the Summary screen

segment.source: Click the Summary button to review your policy choices, and then click Next to finish and to save your policy.
segment.target: Click the Summary button to review your policy choices, and then click Next to finish and to save your policy.

segment.source: A progress bar appears, showing you progress for your policy.
segment.target: A progress bar appears, showing you progress for your policy.

segment.source: After it's done, click Close to return to the Configuration Items page.
segment.target: After it's done, click Close to return to the Configuration Items page.

segment.source: Create Configuration Item wizard, review the Summary screen before creating the policy
segment.target: Create Configuration Item wizard, review the Summary screen before creating the policy

segment.source: Deploy the EDP policy
segment.target: Deploy the EDP policy

segment.source: After you’ve created your EDP policy, you'll need to deploy it to your organization's devices.
segment.target: After you’ve created your EDP policy, you'll need to deploy it to your organization's devices.

segment.source: For info about your deployment options, see these topics:
segment.target: For info about your deployment options, see these topics:

segment.source: Operations and Maintenance for Compliance Settings in Configuration Manager
segment.target: Operations and Maintenance for Compliance Settings in Configuration Manager

segment.source: How to Create Configuration Baselines for Compliance Settings in Configuration Manager
segment.target: How to Create Configuration Baselines for Compliance Settings in Configuration Manager

segment.source: How to Deploy Configuration Baselines in Configuration Manager
segment.target: How to Deploy Configuration Baselines in Configuration Manager

segment.target: Related topics
